{{Other uses|Universalism (disambiguation)}} {{Universalism|expanded=all}} '''Universalism''' is a theological and philosophical concept that some ideas have [[Universal (metaphysics)|universal]] application or applicability.{{citation needed|date=September 2017}} A community that calls itself ''universalist'' may emphasize the universal principles of most religions, and accept others in an inclusive manner. It is centered around the belief in a universal reconciliation between humanity and the divine.{{citation needed|date=September 2017}} For example, some forms of [[Abrahamic religions]] claim the universal value of their doctrine and moral principles, and "feel inclusive"{{huh|date=January 2018}}. [[Christian Universalism]] is focused around the idea of [[universal reconciliation]]. Also known as universal salvation, it is a doctrine stating that every human soul will ultimately be reconciled to God because of divine love and mercy.Otis Ainsworth Skinner (1807-1861), ''A Series of Sermons in Defense of the Doctrine of Universal Salvation'', Page 209, It is not part of mainline Christian doctrine either Catholic or Protestant. "Repentance is a means by which all men are brought into the enjoyment of religion, and we do expect any man will be saved while he continues in sin. However, Unitarian Universalism holds a universal salvation, because is, "we expect all men will repent." A belief in one fundamental truth is another important tenet in Universalism.{{citation needed|date=September 2017}} The living truth is seen as more far-reaching than the national, cultural, or religious boundaries or interpretations of that one truth. As the [[Rig Veda]] states, "Truth is one; sages call it by various names."[https://vedanta.org/what-is-vedanta/harmony-of-religions/ Vedanta Society of Southern California ''Harmony of Religions''] Universalism has had an influence on modern day [[Hinduism]], in turn influencing western modern spirituality.{{sfn|King|2002|p=}}{{Page needed|date=August 2017}} [[Unitarian Universalism]] emphasizes that religion is a universal human quality, and also focuses on the universal principles of most religions. They accept all religions in an inclusive manner. ==Philosophy== ===Universality=== {{Main|Universality (philosophy)}} In philosophy, universality is the notion that universal facts can be discovered and is therefore understood as being in opposition to [[relativism]].Bonnett, A. (2005). ''Anti-Racism''. Routledge. In certain religions, universalism is the quality ascribed to an entity whose existence is consistent throughout the universe. === Moral universalism === {{Main|Moral universalism|Moral particularism}} Moral universalism (also called ''moral objectivism'' or ''universal morality'') is the [[meta-ethics|meta-ethical]] position that some system of [[ethics]] are applied [[universality (philosophy)|universally]]. That system is inclusive of all individuals,{{cite web |url=http://www.philosophypages.com/dy/u.htm#unvby |title=A Dictionary of Philosophical Terms and Names |work=Philosophy Pages |first=Garth|last=Kemerling |date=November 12, 2011 |quote=According to [http://www.philosophypages.com/ph/kant.htm Immanuel Kant] and [http://www.philosophypages.com/dy/h.htm#hare Richard Mervyn Hare]...moral imperatives must be regarded as equally binding on everyone.}} regardless of [[culture]], [[Race (classification of human beings)|race]], [[sex]], [[religion]], [[nationality]], [[sexual orientation]], or any other distinguishing feature.{{cite web |quote=Let us say that moral objectivism maintains that moral judgments are ordinarily true or false in an absolute or universal sense, that some of them are true, and that people sometimes are justified in accepting true moral judgments (and rejecting false ones) on the basis of evidence available to any reasonable and well-informed person. |first=Chris|last=Gowans |title=Moral Relativism |work=The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy (Spring 2012 Edition) |editor=Edward N. Zalta, ed |url=http://plato.stanford.edu/archives/spr2012/entries/moral-relativism/ |date=Dec 9, 2008}} Moral universalism is opposed to [[moral nihilism]] and [[moral relativism]]. However, not all forms of moral universalism are [[moral absolutism|absolutist]], nor do they necessarily [[value monism]]. Many forms of universalism, such as [[utilitarianism]], are non-absolutist. Other forms such as those theorized by [[Isaiah Berlin]], may [[value pluralism|value pluralist ideals.]] ==Religion== ===Bahá'í Faith=== {{Main|Bahá'í Faith and the unity of humanity|Bahá'í Faith and the unity of religion}} In Bahá'í belief, a single God has sent all the historic founders of the world religions in a process of [[Progressive revelation (Bahá'í)|progressive revelation]]. As a result, the major world religions are seen as divine in origin and are continuous in their purpose. In this view, there is unity among the founders of world religions, but each revelation brings a more advanced set of teachings in human history and none are syncretic.{{cite book |title=Paradise and Paradigm: Key Symbols in Persian Christianity and the Bahá'í Faith |location=Albany |publisher=State University of New York Press |year=1999 |page=292 |last=Buck |first=Christopher}} Within this universal view, the unity of humanity is one of the central teachings of the Bahá'í Faith.{{cite book|first=Robert |last=Stockman |title=Sourcebook of the World's Religions |isbn=1-57731-121-3 |publisher=New World Library |year=2000 |editor-first=Joel |editor-last=Beversluis|chapter=The Baha'i Faith |page=7}} The [[Bahá'í teachings]] state that since all humans have been created in the image of God, God does not make any distinction between people with regard to race, colour or religion.{{cite book |last=Smith |first=Peter |year=2008 |title=An Introduction to the Baha'i Faith |publisher=Cambridge University Press |place=Cambridge |isbn=0-521-86251-5 |page=138}} Thus, because all humans have been created equal, they all require equal opportunities and treatment. Hence the Bahá'í view promotes the unity of humanity, and that people's vision should be world-embracing and that people should love the whole world rather than just their nation. The teaching, however, does not equate unity with uniformity; instead the Bahá'í writings advocate the principle of ''unity in diversity'' where the variety in the human race is valued.{{cite book |last=Smith |first=Peter |year=2008 |title=An Introduction to the Baha'i Faith |publisher=Cambridge University Press |place=Cambridge |isbn=0-521-86251-5 |page=139}} Operating on a worldwide basis this cooperative view of the peoples and nations of the planet culminates in a vision of the practicality of the progression in world affairs towards, and the inevitability of, [[world peace]].{{cite encyclopedia |last=Smith |first=Peter |encyclopedia=A concise encyclopedia of the Bahá'í Faith |title=peace |year=2000 |publisher=Oneworld Publications |location=Oxford |isbn=1-85168-184-1 |pages=266–267}} ===Christianity=== {{Main|Christian Universalism}} The fundamental idea of Christian Universalism is [[universal reconciliation]] – that all humans will eventually be saved. They will eventually enter God's kingdom in Heaven, through the grace and works of the lord [[Jesus Christ]].{{cite web|url=http://www.auburn.edu/~allenkc/chr-univ.html |title=What Is Christian Universalism? |publisher=Auburn.edu |date=|accessdate=2017-12-17}} Christian Universalism teaches that an eternal [[Hell]] does not exist, and that it was not what Jesus had taught. They point to historical evidence showing that some early fathers of the church were universalists, and attribute the perpetuating idea of hell to eternal mistranslation.[http://christianuniversalist.org/resources/articles/salvation-conspiracy/ The Salvation Conspiracy: How Hell Became Eternal] Universalists cite numerous Biblical passages which reference the salvation of all beings.{{cite web|author=Gary Amirault |url=http://www.tentmaker.org/tracts/TheFateOfTheWicked.html |title=The Fate of the Wicked |publisher=Tentmaker.org |date= |accessdate=2017-12-17}} In addition, they argue that an eternal hell is both unjust, and against the nature and attributes of a loving God.Guild, E.E. 'Arguments in Favour of Universalism'. http://www.tentmaker.org/books/InFavorCh20.html http://godfire.net/eby/saviour_of_the_world.html http://www.godfire.net/Hellidx.html The remaining beliefs of Christian Universalism are generally compatible with the fundamentals of Christianity{{citation needed|date=August 2017}} * [[God in Christianity|God]] is the loving Parent of all peoples, see [[Love of God]]. * [[Jesus in Christianity|Jesus Christ]] reveals the nature and character of God, and is the spiritual leader of humankind. * Humankind is created with an [[immortal soul]], which death can not end—or a [[Christian mortalism|mortal soul]] that shall be resurrected and preserved by God. A soul which God will not wholly destroy.[http://www.tentmaker.org/books/TheBibleHell.html ''The Bible Hell'']. TentMaker.org. "The immortal soul is not meant, but the life. As though Jesus had said: "Fear Not those who can only kill the body, but rather him, who ''if he chose could'' destroy the soul" * [[Christian views on sin|Sin]] has negative consequences for the sinner either in this life or the [[afterlife]]. All of God's punishments for sin are corrective and remedial. None of such punishments will last forever, or result in the permanent destruction of a soul. Some Christian Universalists believe in the idea of a Purgatorial Hell, or a temporary place of purification that some must undergo before their entrance into Heaven.{{cite book|author=Miriam Van Scott |title=The Encyclopedia of Hell: A Comprehensive Survey of the Underworld |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=N1EnBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA240 |date=10 February 2015 |publisher=St. Martin's Press |isbn=978-1-4668-9119-7 |page=240 |chapter=Purgatorial Hell}} In 1899 the Universalist General Convention, later called the [[Universalist Church of America]], adopted the Five Principles: the belief in God, Jesus Christ, the immortality of the human soul, the reality of sin and [[universal reconciliation]].{{cite web|url=http://www.auburn.edu/~allenkc/prof.html |title=See section entitled "Five Principles of Faith" |publisher=Auburn.edu |date= |accessdate=2011-11-09}} ====History==== {{See also|Universal reconciliation#History|l1=History of Universal Reconciliation}} Universalist writers such as [[George T. Knight (Universalist)|George T. Knight]] have claimed that Universalism was a widely held view among theologians in [[Early Christianity]].[http://www.ccel.org/ccel/schaff/encyc12/Page_96.html [[George T. Knight (Universalist)|George T. Knight]] The Schaff-Herzog Encyclopedia of Religious Knowledge, 1953, vol. 12, p. 96; retrieved 30/04/09] These included such important figures such as Alexandrian scholar [[Origen]] as well as [[Clement of Alexandria]], a Christian theologian. Origen and Clement both included the existence of a non-eternal Hell in their teachings. Hell was remedial, in that it was a place one went to purge one's sins before entering into Heaven.{{cite web|url=http://stanrock.net/2015/05/20/purgatorial-hell-faq/ |title=Purgatorial Hell FAQ |publisher=StanRock.net |date= |accessdate=2016-01-19}} The first undisputed documentations of Christian Universalist ideas occurred in 17th-century England and 18th-century Europe as well as in colonial America. Between 1648-1697 English activist [[Gerrard Winstanley]], writer [[Richard Coppin]], and dissenter [[Jane Leade]], each taught that God would grant all human beings salvation. The same teachings were later spread throughout 18th-century France and America by [[George de Benneville]]. People who taught this doctrine in America would later become known as the [[Universalist Church of America]].{{cite journal |last1=Wyatt |first1=Neal |last2=Dwyer |first2=Tierney V |last3=Dwyer |first3=Tierney V |year=2008 |title=Unitarian Universalism: A Research Guide |url=|journal=Reference & User Services Quarterly |volume=47 |issue=3|pages=210–214 |doi=10.5860/rusq.47n3.210}} The Greek term ''[[apocatastasis|apocatastas]]'' came to be related by some to the beliefs of [[Christian Universalism]], but central to the doctrine was the restitution, or restoration of all sinful beings to God, and to His state of blessedness. In early [[Patristics]], usage of the term is distinct. ====Universalist theology==== {{Main|Christian Universalism}} {{religious text primary|section|date=February 2012}} Universalist theology is grounded in history, scripture and assumptions about the nature of God. [[Thomas Whittemore (Universalist)|Thomas Whittemore]] wrote the book "100 Scriptural Proofs that Jesus Christ Will Save All Mankind"{{cite web|url=http://www.tentmaker.org/books/ScripturalProofs.html |title=100 Scriptural Proofs That Jesus Christ Will Save All Mankind |publisher=Tentmaker.org |date= |accessdate=2017-12-17}} quoting both Old and New Testament verses which support the Universalist viewpoint. Some Bible verses he cites and are cited by other Christian Universalists are: # 1 Corinthians 15:22{{cite web|title=The Fate of the Wicked|url=http://www.tentmaker.org/tracts/TheFateOfTheWicked.html|work=tentmaker.org|publisher=Tentmaker|accessdate=29 June 2012|author=Tentmaker}} #* "For as in Adam '''ALL''' die, so also in Christ shall '''ALL''' be made alive." ([[English Standard Version|ESV]]; emphasis added) # 2 Peter 3:9 #* "'''The Lord''' is not slow to fulfill his promise as some count slowness, but is patient toward you, '''not wishing that any should perish, but that all should reach repentance'''." (ESV; emphasis added) # 1 Timothy 2:3–6 #* "This is good, and pleases God our Savior, who '''wants all men to be saved''' and to come to a knowledge of the truth. For there is one God and one mediator between God and men, the man Christ Jesus, who gave himself as a ransom for '''ALL''' men—the testimony given in its proper time." (NIV; emphasis added) # 1 John 2:2 #* "He is the atoning sacrifice for our sins, and not only for ours but also for the sins of the whole world." (NIV) # 1 Timothy 4:10 #* "For to this end we toil and strive, because we have our hope set on the living God, who is the '''Savior of all people, especially of those who believe'''." (ESV; emphasis added) # Romans 11:32 #* "For God has bound all men over to disobedience so that he may have mercy on them all." (NIV) ====Mistranslations==== Christian Universalists point towards the mistranslations of the Greek word αιών (Lit. aion), as giving rise to the idea of Eternal Hell, and the idea that some people will not be saved.[http://www.tentmaker.org/articles/EternalPunishmentNotTrueToGreek.html "Eternal" Punishment (Matthew 25:46) Is NOT Found In The Greek New Testament.][https://carm.org/look-word-aionion A look at the word "aionion"] This Greek word is the origin of the modern English word [[aeon]], which refers to a period of time or an epoch. The 19th century theologian [[Marvin Vincent]] wrote about the word ''aion'', and the supposed connotations of "eternal" or "temporal":
'''Aion''', transliterated '''''aeon''''', is a period of longer or shorter duration, having a beginning and an end, and complete in itself. [...] Neither the noun nor the adjective, in themselves, carry the sense of ''endless'' or ''everlasting''."{{cite web|last=Vincent|first=Marvin|title=Note on Olethron Aionion (eternal destruction)|url=http://www.auburn.edu/~allenkc/vincent.html|work=Word Studies in the New Testament|accessdate=18 June 2012}}
Dr. Ken Vincent writes that "When it (aion) was translated into Latin Vulgate, "aion" became "aeternam" which means "eternal". ====New Thought==== {{Main|New Thought}} {{unreferenced section|date=February 2012}} [[Unity Church]], [[Religious Science]], and [[Divine Science]] are denominations within the New Thought movement. Each teaches that there is a common thread of truth at the heart of all religions. New Thought is an ever-evolving belief system which will incorporate ''Truth'' where ever it is found, hence the name ''New Thought''. ''All is God, But God transcends all''. ====Unitarian Universalism==== {{Main|Unitarian Universalism}} Unitarian Universalism (UU) is a theologically liberal religion characterized by a "free and responsible search for truth and meaning".(The 4th principle of Unitarian Universalism)[http://www.uua.org/visitors/6798.shtml UUA.org Seven principles] Unitarian Universalists do not share a [[creed]]; rather, they are unified by their shared search for [[spiritual growth]] and by the understanding that an individual's theology is a result of that search and not a result of obedience to an authoritarian requirement. Unitarian Universalists draw from all major world religions{{cite web|url=http://www.adherents.com/Religions_By_Adherents.html#Rastafarianism |title=Major Religions Ranked by Size |publisher=Adherents.com |date= |accessdate=April 19, 2013}} and many different theological sources and have a wide range of beliefs and practices. While having its origins in Christianity, UU is no longer a Christian church. As of 2006, fewer than about 20% of Unitarian Universalists identified themselves as Christian.{{cite book |last=Ford |first=James Ishmael |title=Zen Master Who? |publisher=[[Wisdom Publications]] |year=2006 |page=187 |isbn=0-86171-509-8}} Contemporary Unitarian Universalism espouses a pluralist approach to religious belief, whereby members may describe themselves as [[Humanism|humanist]], agnostic, [[deist]], [[atheist]], pagan, Christian, [[monotheist]], [[pantheism|pantheist]], [[polytheist]], or assume no label at all. The [[Unitarian Universalist Association]] (UUA) was formed in 1961, a consolidation of the [[American Unitarian Association]], established in 1825, and the Universalist Church of America,Harvard Divinity School: [http://div.hds.harvard.edu/library/bms/merger_timeline_1900s.html Timeline of Significant Events in the Merger of the Unitarian and Universalist Churches During the 1900s] established in 1866. It is headquartered in [[Boston]], and mainly serves churches in the United States. The [[Canadian Unitarian Council]] became an independent body in 2002.CUC-UUA Tradition. Canadian Unitarian Council [http://cuc.ca/who_we_are/cuc-uua_transition.htm Growing Vital Religious Communities In Canada] =====Non-religious Universalism===== Universalism is not only a set of values, but a worldview to which any can subscribe if they observe and believe in the universality of the human experience—and that of all sentient life—and work to uphold the principles, ethics, and actions that safeguard these fundamental things.{{cite web|title=Unitarian Universalism |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/religion/religions/atheism/types/unitarianuniversalism.shtml|publisher=BBC|accessdate=4 May 2012}} Indeed, many Universalists may be attracted to the logic of universally applicable principles, rather than any belief or dogma. Human unity, solidarity, and the perceived need for a sustainable and socially conscious global order are among the tendencies of non-religious Universalist thought.{{cite web|title=Unitarian Universalism|url=http://www.religioustolerance.org/u-u.htm|accessdate=4 May 2012}} ===Hinduism=== Author David Frawley says that Hinduism has a "background universalism" and its teachings contain a "universal relevance."[http://www.haindavakeralam.com/pluralism-and-universalism-within-hinduism-david-frawley-hk5500 ''Pluralism and Universalism Within Hinduism''] "Hindu teachings were also denigrated accordingly and the deeper philosophies of Hinduism were often ignored, especially their universal relevance. For conversion purposes it was easier to define Hinduism in a limited way as a local phenomenon only. Yet the universality of Hindu teachings continued, though few outside of India understood this until recent years. This background universalism of Sanatana Dharma affords Hinduism a synthetic tendency, an ability to incorporate within itself a diversity of views and approaches, including at times those from groups outside of Hinduism or even opposed to Hinduism. Because of this syncretic view, sometimes Hinduism is equated with a blind universalism that accepts without discrimination anything that calls itself religious or spiritual, as if differences of spiritual teachings did not matter in any way. While this may be true of some Hindus, the Hindu tradition also contains a lively tradition of free debate on all aspects of theology, philosophy and metaphysics, showing differences as well as similarities, and not simply equating all teachings as they are. A good example of this is the debates between the dualistic and non-dualistic schools of Vedantic philosophy, but many other examples exist as well. The different sects within Hinduism have always been free to disagree, though each sect has its particular guidelines and there is an overall respect for Dharma." [[Hinduism]] is also naturally [[Religious pluralism|religiously pluralistic]].[https://www.hafsite.org/hinduism-101/hinduism-basics Hindu American Foundation "Hinduism Basics"] A well-known ''[[Rig Veda|Rig Vedic]]'' hymn says: "Truth is One, though the sages know it variously."Rig Veda 1.164.46 Similarly, in the ''[[Bhagavad Gita|Bhagavad Gītā]]'' (4:11), God, manifesting as an incarnation, states: "As people approach me, so I receive them. All paths lead to me."[https://books.google.com/books?id=56UM3BIvbHYC&printsec=frontcover&dq=easwaran+1586380273&lr=&cd=1#v=onepage&q=as%20people%20approach%20me&f=false Page 194] in [[Eknath Easwaran]] (2008). ''[[God Makes the Rivers to Flow|Timeless wisdom: Passages for meditation from the world's saints & sages]]'' (see [[God Makes the Rivers to Flow|article]]). Tomales, CA: Nilgiri Press. {{ISBN|1-58638-027-3}}. Similar to [[Eknath Easwaran]] (2007). ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=a-Oh_-rK5SQC&printsec=frontcover&dq=easwaran+1586380192&lr=&cd=1#v=onepage&q=approach%20me&f=false The Bhagavad Gita]'', 2nd ed. Tomales, CA: Nilgiri Press, p. 117. ISBN 1586380192 (which substitutes "they" for "people"). Transliteration from Winthrop Sargeant (1984). ''The Bhagavad Gita''. Albany: State University of New York Press, p. 211. {{ISBN|0-87395-831-4}}, which translates the same passage as "They who, in whatever way, take refuge in Me, them I reward." The Hindu religion has no theological difficulties in accepting degrees of truth in other religions. Hinduism emphasizes that everyone actually worships the same God, whether one knows it or not.See Swami Bhaskarananda, ''Essentials of Hinduism'' (Viveka Press 2002) {{ISBN|1-884852-04-1}} While Hinduism has an openness and tolerance towards other religions, it also has a wide range of diversity within it.[https://www.hafsite.org/hinduism-101/hinduism-basics Hindu American Foundation ''Hinduism Basics'' "It is a richly diverse family of philosophies, traditions, and practices that have been followed primarily throughout Asia for thousands of years."] There are considered to be six orthodox Hindu schools of philosophy/theology,[http://veden-akademie.de/index.php?article_id=154&clang=1 "Shat-darshana: The Philosophical Schools of Sanatana Dharma"] as well as multiple unorthodox or "hetrodox" traditions called [[darshanas]].[http://www.clearias.com/indian-philosophy-schools/ ''Indian Philosophy: Orthodox and Heterodox Schools''] ====Hindu Universalism==== {{Main|Neo-Vedanta|Hindu reform movements}} ''Hindu Universalism'', also called ''Neo-Vedanta''[http://bharatabharati.wordpress.com/2012/02/15/neo-vedanta-the-problem-with-hindu-universalism-frank-gaetano-morales/ Frank Morales, ''Neo-Vedanta: The problem with Hindu Universalism''] and ''neo-Hinduism'',{{sfn|King|2002|p=93}} is a modern interpretation of Hinduism which developed in response to western colonialism and [[orientalism]]. It denotes the ideology that all religions are true and therefore worthy of toleration and respect.{{cite book|title=What Is Hinduism?: Modern Adventures Into a Profound Global Faith|year=2007|publisher=Himalayan Academy Publications|isbn=1934145009|page=416|author=Editors of Hinduism Today}} It is a modern interpretation that aims to present Hinduism as a "homogenized ideal of Hinduism"{{sfn|Yelle|2012|p=338}} with Advaita Vedanta as its central doctrine.{{sfn|King|2002|p=135}} For example, it presents that: {{quote|... an imagined "integral unity" that was probably little more than an "imagined" view of the religious life that pertained only to a cultural elite and that empirically speaking had very little reality "on the ground," as it were, throughout the centuries of cultural development in the South Asian region.{{sfn|Larson|2012|p=313}}}} Hinduism embraces universalism by conceiving the whole world as a single family that deifies the one truth, and therefore it accepts all forms of beliefs and dismisses labels of distinct religions which would imply a division of identity.(Rigveda 1:164:46) "Ekam sat vipra bahudha vadanti" - Truth is one; sages call it many names(Maha Upanishad: Chapter 6, Verse 72) "[[Vasudhaiva Kutumbakam]]" - The entire world is a one big family{{Cite book |last=Badlani |first=Hiro |title=Hinduism: Path of the Ancient Wisdom |publisher=[[iUniverse]] |year=2008 |page=303 |url=https://books.google.com/?id=8NrQhyxH-GgC |isbn=978-0-595-70183-4}}{{Self-published inline|certain=yes|date=December 2017}} This modernised re-interpretation has become a broad current in Indian culture,{{sfn|King|2002|p=135}}{{sfn|Sinari|2000}} extending far beyond the [[Dashanami Sampradaya]], the Advaita Vedanta Sampradaya founded by [[Adi Shankara]]. An early exponent of Hindu Universalism was [[Ram Mohan Roy]], who established the [[Brahmo Samaj]].{{sfn|Ghazi|2010}} Hindu Universalism was popularised in the 20th century in both India and the west by [[Vivekananda]]{{sfn|Michaelson|2009|p=79-81}}{{sfn|King|2002|p=135}} and [[Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan]].{{sfn|King|2002|p=135}} Veneration for all other religions was articulated by [[Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi|Gandhi]]: {{quote|After long study and experience, I have come to the conclusion that [1] all religions are true; [2] all religions have some error in them; [3] all religions are almost as dear to me as my own Hinduism, in as much as all human beings should be as dear to one as one's own close relatives. My own veneration for other faiths is the same as that for my own faith; therefore no thought of conversion is possible.M. K. Gandhi, ''All Men Are Brothers: Life and Thoughts of Mahatma Gandhi as told in his own words'', Paris, UNESCO 1958, p 60.}} Western orientalists played an important role in this popularisation, regarding Vedanta to be the "central theology of Hinduism".{{sfn|King|2002|p=135}} Oriental scholarship portrayed Hinduism as a "single world religion",{{sfn|King|2002|p=135}} and denigrated the heterogeneousity of Hindu beliefs and practices as 'distortions' of the basic teachings of Vedanta.{{sfn|King|1999|p=135}}{{Citation not found}} ===Islam=== {{Further|Ummah|Divisions of the world in Islam|People of the Book|Dhimmi|Dawah|}} {{Original Research|date=June 2018}} Islam recognizes to a certain extent the validity of the [[Abrahamic religions]], the [[Quran]] identifying Jews, Christians, and "[[Sabians|Sabi'un]]" (usually taken as a reference to the [[Mandaeans]]) as "people of the Book" (''ahl al-kitab''). Later Islamic theologians expanded this definition to include [[Zoroastrians]], and later even Hindus, as the early Islamic empire brought many people professing these religions under its dominion, but the Qur'an explicitly identifies only Jews, Christians, and [[Sabians]] as People of the Book.{{cite book|last=Crone|first=Patricia|title=God's Rule: Government and Islam: Six Centuries of Medieval Islamic Political Thought|year=2005|publisher=Columbia University Press|isbn=978-0-231-13291-6|page=472}}{{Request quotation|date=November 2015}}, {{cite book|last1=Lapidus|first1=Ira M.|title=Ira M. Lapidus|date=2014|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=9780521514309|page=1000|url=https://books.google.com/?id=kFJNBAAAQBAJ&dq=A+History+of+Islamic+Societies}}{{failed verification|date=November 2015}}, {{cite book|last1=Karsh|first1=Efraim|title=Islamic Imperialism: A History|date=2007|publisher=Yale University Press|isbn=9780300122633|page=304 |url=http://www.ahandfulofleaves.org/documents/Islamic%20Imperialism_A%20History_2nd%20Ed_Karsh.pdf}}{{failed verification|date=November 2015}} The relation between Islam and universalism has assumed crucial importance in the context of [[political Islam]] or [[Islamism]], particularly in reference to [[Sayyid Qutb]], a leading member of the [[Muslim Brotherhood]] movement, and one of the key contemporary philosophers of Islam.{{Cite journal |url=https://www.academia.edu/5611020/The_Inclusive_Dynamics_of_Islamic_Universalism_From_the_Vantage_Point_of_Sayyid_Qutb_s_Critical_Philosophy|title=The Inclusive Dynamics of Islamic Universalism: From the Vantage Point of Sayyid Qutb's Critical Philosophy|last=Mura|first=Andrea|date=2014|journal=Comparative Philosophy|access-date=2015-05-12}} There are several views within Islam with respect to Universalism. According to the most inclusive teachings, common among the [[liberal Muslim movements]], all monotheistic religions or people of the book have a chance of salvation. For example, Surah 2:62,256 states that:1. S. A. Rahman, Punishment of Apostasy in Islam, Institute of Islamic Culture, Lahore, 1972{{unreliable source?|date=October 2017}}{{page needed|date=October 2017}} {{quote|Verily! Those who believe and those who are Jews and Christians, and Sabians, whoever believes in Allah and the Last Day and do righteous good deeds shall have their reward with their Lord, on them shall be no fear, nor shall they grieve...let there be no compulsion in religion}} However, the most exclusive teachings disagree. For example, the [[Salafi]] refer to Surah 9:5,29:{{citation needed|date=November 2015}} {{quote|Then, when the sacred months have passed, slay the idolaters [''mushrikun''] wherever ye find them, and take them, and besiege them, and lay in wait in every stratagem of war. But if they repent and establish worship and pay the ''Zakat'', then leave their way free. Lo! Allah is Forgiving, Merciful [...] Fight against such of those who have been given the Scripture [i.e. people of the book] as believe not in Allah nor the Last Day, and forbid not that which Allah hath forbidden by His messenger, and follow not the Religion of Truth, until they pay the ''jizya'' readily, being brought low [in submission].}} The interpretation of all of these passages are hotly contested amongst various schools of thought, traditionalist and reform-minded, and branches of Islam, from the reforming [[Quranism]] and [[Ahmadiyya]] to the ultra-traditionalist [[Salafi]], as is the doctrine of abrogation (''[[Naskh (tafsir)|naskh]]'') which is used to determine which verses take precedence, based on reconstructed chronology, with later verses superseding earlier ones. The traditional chronology places Surah 9 as the last or second-to-last surah revealed, thus, in traditional exegesis, it gains a large power of abrogation, and verses 9:5,29,73 are held to have abrogated 2:256{{cite book|last=Ibn Kathir|first=Ismail (1301-1373)|title=Tafsir al-Qur'an al-Aziz (Tafsir Ibn Kathir)|year=2000|publisher=Maktaba Darussalam|location=Riyadh, Saudi Arabia|isbn=978-1-59144-020-8|page=6608|edition=English Abridged|editor=Sheikh Safiur-Rahman Al-Mubarakpuri|language=English, Arabic}} The ahadith also play a major role in this, and different schools of thought assign different weightings and rulings of authenticity to different hadith, with the four schools of Sunni thought accepting the Six Authentic Collections, generally along with the [[Muwatta Imam Malik]]. Depending on the level of acceptance of rejection of certain traditions, the interpretation of the Koran can be changed immensely, from the Qur'anists and Ahmadiyya who reject the ahadith, to the Salafi, or ''ahl al-hadith'', who hold the entirety of the traditional collections in great reverence. Traditional Islam{{cite web|url=http://english.islamway.com/bindex.php?section=article&id=211|title=Dar Al-Islam And Dar Al-Harb: Its Definition and Significance|publisher=IslamWay (English)|date=2002-05-27|accessdate=2015-05-12|last=Khalil|first=Ahmed}} views the world as bipartite, consisting of the House of Islam, that is, where people live under the [[Sharia]]; and the House of War, that is, where the people do not live under Sharia, which must be proselytized{{cite book|last=Ye'or|first=Bat|title=The Dhimmi: Jews and Christians Under Islam|year=1985|publisher=Farleign Dickinson University Press |page=444|isbn=978-0838632628}}{{cite book|last=Ye'or|first=Bat|title=The Decline of Eastern Christianity Under Islam: From Jihad to Dhimmitude: 7th–20th Centuries |publisher=Farleigh Dickinson University Press|isbn=978-0-8386-3688-6|page=522}} using whatever resources available, including, in some traditionalist and conservative interpretations,Ibn Kathir's Tafsir al-Qur'an al-Aziz the use of violence, as holy struggle in the path of God,Sayyid Qutb ''Milestones'' to either convert its inhabitants to Islam, or to rule them under the Shariah (cf. [[dhimmi]]).{{cite book|last=Durie |first=Mark|title=The Third Choice: Islam, Dhimmitude and Freedom|year=2010|publisher=Deror Books|isbn=978-0-9807223-1-4|page=288}}{{cite book|last=Ye'or |first=Bat|title=Islam and Dhimmitude: Where Civilizations Collide|year=2001|publisher=Farleigh Dickinson University Press|isbn=978-0-8386-3942-9|page=528}} ===Judaism=== {{Main|Jewish views on religious pluralism}} {{See also|Noahidism}} Judaism teaches that God [[Jews as the chosen people|chose the Jewish people]] to be in a unique covenant with God, and one of their beliefs is that Jewish people were charged by the [[Torah]] with a specific mission—to be a light unto the nations, and to exemplify the covenant with God as described in the Torah to other nations. This view does not preclude a belief that God also has a relationship with other peoples—rather, Judaism holds that God had entered into a covenant with all humanity as [[Noahidism|Noachides]], and that Jews and non-Jews alike have a relationship with God, as well as being universal in the sense that it is open to all mankind.{{cite journal |last1=Polish |first1=David |year=1985 |title=Covenant-Jewish Universalism and Particularism |journal=Judaism |volume=34 |issue=3 |page=284 }} An on-line organization, the Jewish Spiritual Leaders Institute founded and led by [[Steven Blane]], who calls himself an "American Jewish Universalist Rabbi", believes in a more inclusive version of Jewish Universalism, stating that "God equally chose all nations to be lights unto the world, and we have much to learn and share with each other. We can only accomplish [[Tikkun Olam]] by our unconditional acceptance of each other's peaceful doctrines."{{cite web|title=Jewish Universalism|url=http://www.jsli.net/jewish-universalism|work=Jewish Spiritual Leaders Institute|publisher=Google Inc|accessdate=29 June 2012|author=Staff}} ===Manichaeism=== {{main|Manichaeism}} Manichaeism, like Christian [[Gnosticism]] and [[Zurvanism]], was inherently universalist.{{cite journal|title=Manichaeism in the Early Sasanian Empire|author=Manfred Hutter |date=January 1993|publisher=BRILL|jstor=3270395|volume=40}}{{page needed|date=November 2015}} ===Sikhism=== {{multiple issues|section=yes| {{refimprove section|date=February 2012}} {{expand section|date=February 2012}} }} In [[Sikhism]], all the religions of the world are compared to rivers flowing into a single ocean. Although the [[Sikh gurus]] did not agree with the practices of [[fasting]], [[idolatry]] and pilgrimage during their times, they stressed that all religions should be tolerated and considered on equal footing. The Sikh scripture, the [[Guru Granth Sahib]], contains the writings of not just the Sikh guru themselves, but the writings of several Hindu and Muslim saints, known as the ''[[Bhagat]]s''. The very first word of the Sikh scripture is "Ik", followed by "Oh-ang-kar". This literally means that there is only one god, and that one is wholesome, inclusive of the whole universe. It further goes on to state that all of creation, and all energy is part of this primordial being. As such, it is described in scripture over and over again, that all that occurs is part of the divine will, and as such, has to be accepted. It occurs for a reason, even if its beyond the grasp of one person to understand. Although Sikhism does not teach that men are created as an [[image of God]], it states that the essence of the One is to be found throughout all of its creation.{{citation needed|date=November 2015}} As was said by Yogi Bhajan, the man who is credited with having brought Sikhism to the West:
"If you can't see God in all, you can't see God at all". (Sri Singh Sahib, Yogi Bhajan){{cite web|url=https://www.sikhdharma.org/about-the-siri-singh-sahib-yogi-bhajan/|title=About the Siri Singh Sahib – Sikh Dharma International|website=www.sikhdharma.org|access-date=2017-11-02}}
The First Sikh Guru, [[Guru Nanak]] said himself:
"There is no Hindu, there is no Muslim".{{cite web|url=http://www.sikhiwiki.org/index.php/There_is_no_Hindu_and_no_Musalman|title=There is no Hindu and no Musalman - SikhiWiki, free Sikh encyclopedia.|website=www.sikhiwiki.org|access-date=2016-11-19}}{{cite web|url=http://www.sikhs.org/guru1.htm|title=Sikhism Religion of the Sikh People|website=www.sikhs.org|access-date=2016-11-19}}{{cite web |url=http://www.gurmat.info/sms/smspublications/gurunanakforchildren/chapter4/#No%20Hindu,%20and%20no%20Muslim|title=Guru Nanak (for Children) - No Hindu, and no Muslim|last=Munde |first=Amarpreet Singh|website=www.gurmat.info|access-date=2016-11-19}}
By this, Guru Nanak meant that there is no distinction between religion in God's eyes, whether polytheist, monotheist, [[pantheist]], or even atheist, all that one needs to gain salvation is purity of heart, tolerance of all beings, compassion and kindness. Unlike many of the major world religions, Sikhism does not have [[proselytism|missionaries]], instead it believes men have the freedom to find their own path to [[salvation]]. ===Zoroastrianism=== {{main|Zoroastrianism}} Some varieties of Zoroastrian (such as [[Zurvanism]]) are universalistic in application to all races, but not necessarily universalist in the sense of universal salvation.Jonathan Porter Berkey ''The formation of Islam: religion and society in the Near East'' 2003 p28 "This is not to say that there was no universalist dimension to Zoroastrian religious life; but what universalism there was derived directly, and to a greater degree than in the case of Rome and Christianity, from the explicit connection between religion and the state."{{failed verification|date=November 2015}} ==Critics== In his book ''The Miracle of Theism: Arguments for and against the Existence of God'', the Australian philosopher [[J. L. Mackie]] noted that whilst in the past a miracle performed by Jesus had served as proof to Christians that he was the 'one true God', and that a miracle performed by another religion's deity had served as a (contradictory) proof to its own adherents, the universalist approach resulted in any such miracle being accepted as a validation of all religions, a situation that he characterised as "Miracle-workers of the world, unite!"{{cite book |author-last1=Mackie |author-first1=J. L. |title=The Miracle of Theism: Arguments for and against the Existence of God |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]] |date=November 1982 |isbn=978-0198246824|quote="It is no longer 'The heathen in his blindness…', but rather 'We worship the same god, but under different names and in different ways’. Carried far enough, this modern tendency would allow Christian miracles to support, not undermine, belief in the supernatural achievements of stone-age witch doctors and medicine men, and vice versa. It is as if someone had coined the slogan, Miracle-workers of the world, unite!"|page=15}} ==See also== {{Portal|Religion}} {{Div col|colwidth=25em}} * [[Ananda Marga]] * Christianity: ** [[Liberal Catholic Church]] ** [[Primitive Baptist Universalist]] ** [[Religious Society of Friends]] ** [[Schwarzenau Brethren]] ** [[Swedenborgianism]] ([[The New Church]]) ** [[Trinitarian Universalism]] * [[Comparative religion]] * [[Ecumenism]] * [[Hypothetical universalism]] * [[George MacDonald]] * [[Mahatma Gandhi Foundation]] * [[Omnism]] * [[Perennial philosophy]] * [[Post-theism]] * [[Religious liberalism]] * [[Religious pluralism]] * [[Subud]] * [[Universal Sufism]] {{colend}} ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==Sources== * {{cite journal |last=Mura |first=Andrea |year=2014 |title=The Inclusive Dynamics of Islamic Universalism: From the Vantage Point of Sayyid Qutb's Critical Philosophy |journal=Comparative Philosophy |volume=5 |issue=1 |pages=29–54 |issn=2151-6014 |url=https://www.academia.edu/5611020/The_Inclusive_Dynamics_of_Islamic_Universalism_From_the_Vantage_Point_of_Sayyid_Qutbs_Critical_Philosophy}} * {{Cite journal |last=Casara |first=E. |year=1984 |title=Universalism in America}} * {{Cite journal |last=Ghazi |first=Abidullah Al-Ansari |ref=harv |year=2010 |title=Raja Rammohun Roy: Encounter with Islam and Christianity and the Articulation of Hindu Self-Consciousness |publisher=Xlibris Corporation }}{{Self-published inline|certain=yes|date=December 2017}} * {{Citation|last=King|first=Richard|author-link=Richard E. [[File:The_emotional_warm_glow_of_helping_others.jpg|alt=|thumb|330x330px|The emotional warm glow of helping others]] '''Warm-glow giving''' is an economic theory describing the emotional reward of giving to others. According to the original warm-glow model developed by [[James Andreoni|Andreoni]] (1989, 1990),<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Andreoni|first=James|date=1989|title=Giving with Impure Altruism: Applications to Charity and Ricardian Equivalence|url=http://www.jstor.org/stable/1833247|journal=Journal of Political Economy|volume=97|issue=6|pages=1447–1458}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Andreoni|first=James|date=1990|title=Impure Altruism and Donations to Public Goods: A Theory of Warm-Glow Giving|url=http://www.jstor.org/stable/2234133|journal=The Economic Journal|volume=100|issue=401|pages=464–477|doi=10.2307/2234133}}</ref> people experience a sense of joy and satisfaction for "doing their part" to help others. This satisfaction - or "''warm glow"'' - represents the selfish pleasure derived from "doing good", regardless of the actual impact of one's generosity. Within the warm-glow framework, people may be "impurely altruistic", meaning they simultaneously maintain both altruistic and egoistic (selfish) motivations for giving. Whereas "pure altruists" (sometimes referred to as "perfect altruists")<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kohler|first=Stefan|date=2011|title=Altruism and fairness in experimental decisions|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jebo.2011.02.014|journal=Journal of Economic Behavior & Organization|volume=80|issue=1|pages=101–109|doi=10.1016/j.jebo.2011.02.014|issn=0167-2681|via=}}</ref> are motivated solely by the desire to provide for a recipient, impure altruists are also motivated by the joy of giving (warm glow).<ref name=":2" /> Importantly, warm glow is distinctly non-pecuniary,<ref name=":7">{{Cite book|title=The Valmont Effect: The Warm-Glow Theory of Philanthropy|last=Elster|first=Jon|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2011|isbn=978-0-19-973907-3|location=|pages=67-83}}</ref><ref name=":8">{{Cite journal|last=Feddersen|first=Timothy|date=2009|title=The Foundations of Warm-Glow Theory|url=https://www.ssc.wisc.edu/~mrostek/warm-glowd%2010-08-09.pdf|journal=Working Paper|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> meaning it arises independent of the possibility of financial reward. Therefore, the warm glow phenomenon is distinct from [[reciprocal altruism]], which may imply a direct financial incentive.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Morelli|first=Sylvia A.|last2=Lieberman|first2=Matthew D.|last3=Zaki|first3=Jamil|date=2015|title=The Emerging Study of Positive Empathy|url=https://escholarship.org/uc/item/12m108p4|journal=Social and Personality Psychology Compass|language=en|volume=9|issue=2|pages=57–68|doi=10.1111/spc3.12157|issn=1751-9004|via=}}</ref> Warm-glow giving is a useful economic framework to consider public good provision, collective action problems, charitable giving, and gifting behavior. The existence of a warm glow helps to explain the absence of complete crowding-out of private giving by public grants, as predicted by classical economic models under the neutrality hypothesis.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Andreoni|first=James|last2=Payne|first2=A. Abigail|date=2003|title=Do Government Grants to Private Charities Crowd Out Giving or Fund-raising?|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1257/000282803322157098|journal=American Economic Review|volume=93|issue=3|pages=792–812|doi=10.1257/000282803322157098|issn=0002-8282|via=}}</ref><ref name=":24">{{Cite journal|last=Menges|first=Roland|last2=Schroeder|first2=Carsten|last3=Traub|first3=Stefan|date=2005|title=Altruism, Warm Glow and the Willingness-to-Donate for Green Electricity: An Artefactual Field Experiment|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s10640-005-3365-y|journal=Environmental & Resource Economics|volume=31|issue=4|pages=431–458|doi=10.1007/s10640-005-3365-y|issn=0924-6460|via=}}</ref> Outside of economics, warm glow has been applied to sociology,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.psychologytoday.com/us/blog/culture-conscious/201608/is-the-warm-glow-giving-universal|title=Is the Warm Glow of Giving Universal?|website=Psychology Today|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-16}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=|title=The social meaning of money|last=Zelizer|first=Viviana|publisher=Princeton University Press|others=|year=1997|isbn=9780691176031|edition=New Princeton paperback edition|location=Princeton, New Jersey|pages=Chapter 4|oclc=962353754}}</ref> political science,<ref name=":21">{{Cite journal|last=Riker|first=William H.|last2=Ordeshook|first2=Peter C.|date=1968|title=A Theory of the Calculus of Voting|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1017/s000305540011562x|journal=American Political Science Review|volume=62|issue=01|pages=25–42|doi=10.1017/s000305540011562x|issn=0003-0554|via=}}</ref> environmental policy,<ref name=":12">{{Cite journal|last=D'Amato|first=Alessio|last2=Mancinelli|first2=Susanna|last3=Zoli|first3=Mariangela|date=2014|title=Two Shades of (Warm) Glow: multidimensional intrinsic motivation, waste reduction and recycling|url=http://www.sustainability-seeds.org/papers/RePec/srt/wpaper/2114.pdf|journal=Working Paper|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref><ref name=":13">{{Cite journal|last=van der Linden|first=Sander|date=2015|title=Intrinsic motivation and pro-environmental behaviour|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/nclimate2669|journal=Nature Climate Change|volume=5|issue=7|pages=612–613|doi=10.1038/nclimate2669|issn=1758-678X|via=}}</ref> healthcare,<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=http://worldcat.org/oclc/987462476|title=Doing good better effective altruism and a radical new way to make a difference|last=VerfasserIn.|first=MacAskill, William,|isbn=9781783350513|oclc=987462476}}</ref> and business.<ref name=":29">{{Cite journal|last=Habel|first=Johannes|last2=Schons|first2=Laura Marie|last3=Alavi|first3=Sascha|last4=Wieseke|first4=Jan|date=2016|title=Warm Glow or Extra Charge? The Ambivalent Effect of Corporate Social Responsibility Activities on Customers’ Perceived Price Fairness|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1509/jm.14.0389|journal=Journal of Marketing|volume=80|issue=1|pages=84–105|doi=10.1509/jm.14.0389|issn=0022-2429|via=}}</ref> Conceptually, warm-glow giving is related to the notion of a "helper's high"<ref name=":18">{{Cite journal|last=Baraz|first=James|last2=Alexander|first2=Shoshana|date=2010|title=The Helper's High|url=https://greatergood.berkeley.edu/article/item/the_helpers_high|journal=Greater Good Magazine|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> and appears to be resilient across cultures.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/800031934|title=Happy money : the science of smarter spending|last=2013|first=Dunn, Elizabeth,|date=2013|publisher=Simon & Schuster|others=Norton, Michael I.,|year=|isbn=9781451665062|edition=1st Simon & Schuster hardcover ed|location=New York|pages=|oclc=800031934}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Dunn|first=Elizabeth W.|last2=Aknin|first2=Lara B.|last3=Norton|first3=Michael I.|date=2014|title=Prosocial Spending and Happiness|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1177/0963721413512503|journal=Current Directions in Psychological Science|volume=23|issue=1|pages=41–47|doi=10.1177/0963721413512503|issn=0963-7214|via=}}</ref>
== Background in moral philosophy == [[File:Thomas_Hobbes_(portrait).jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Thomas_Hobbes_(portrait).jpg|alt=|left|thumb|Thomas Hobbes was a stern advocate of psychological egoism, claiming "No man giveth but with intention of good to himself"<ref>{{Cite book|url=http://worldcat.org/oclc/559835539|title=Leviathan (1651)|last=Hobbes|first=Thomas|date=|publisher=Broadview Press|year=1981|isbn=9781554810031|location=|pages=Chapter 15|oclc=559835539}}</ref>]] Warm glow is built upon the idea of impure altruism: the blend of both altruistic and egoistic desires to help others.<ref name=":14">{{Cite journal|last=Andreoni|first=James|date=1989|title=Giving with Impure Altruism: Applications to Charity and Ricardian Equivalence|url=http://www.jstor.org/stable/1833247|journal=Journal of Political Economy|volume=97|issue=6|pages=1447–1458}}</ref> Philosophers have debated this idea since the time of the ancient Greeks.<ref name=":3">{{Cite book|url=http://worldcat.org/oclc/470534226|title=The morality of happiness|last=Julia|first=Annas,|date=1993|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=0195096525|oclc=470534226}}</ref> In the [[Socratic dialogue|Socratic ''dialogues'']], motivation may be traced to an egotistic concern for one's own welfare, thus denying the plausibility of pure altruism.<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Annas|first=Julia|date=1977|title=Plato and Aristotle on Friendship and Altruism|url=http://www.jstor.org/stable/2253312|journal=Mind|volume=86|issue=344|pages=532–554}}</ref> Similarly, [[Plato]]'s organization of motivations as responses to hunger-based desires highlights the foundational importance of egoism in all social interactions.<ref name=":3" /> However, in [[Nicomachean Ethics|Nichomachean Ethics]]<nowiki/>and [[Eudemian Ethics]], Aristotle considers both the possibility and necessity of altruism to fulfill high-order eudaimonic goals<ref name=":4" />, thus setting the stage for an ongoing philosophical debate. [[Thomas Hobbes|Hobbes]], [[Immanuel Kant|Kant]], [[Friedrich Nietzsche|Nietzsche]], [[Jeremy Bentham|Bentham]], [[John Stuart Mill|J.S. Mill]]<nowiki/>argued against the possibility of pure altruism<ref name=":19">{{Citation|last=Doris|first=John|title=Moral Psychology: Empirical Approaches|date=2017|url=https://plato.stanford.edu/archives/win2017/entries/moral-psych-emp/|work=The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy|editor-last=Zalta|editor-first=Edward N.|edition=Winter 2017|publisher=Metaphysics Research Lab, Stanford University|access-date=2018-11-16|last2=Stich|first2=Stephen|last3=Phillips|first3=Jonathan|last4=Walmsley|first4=Lachlan}}</ref>and advanced the doctrine of [[psychological egoism]],<ref>{{Citation|last=Kraut|first=Richard|title=Altruism|date=2018|url=https://plato.stanford.edu/archives/spr2018/entries/altruism/|work=The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy|editor-last=Zalta|editor-first=Edward N.|edition=Spring 2018|publisher=Metaphysics Research Lab, Stanford University|access-date=2018-11-08}}</ref> while others ([[Joseph Butler|Butler]], [[David Hume|Hume]], [[Jean-Jacques Rousseau|Rousseau]], [[Adam Smith]], [[Thomas Nagel|Nagel]]) argued for the existence of altruistic motives.<ref name=":19" /> Conceptually, the warm-glow model represents a stylized compromise between these two perspectives, allowing for individuals to be purely altruistic, purely egoistic, or impurely altruistic.<ref name=":22">{{Cite journal|last=Andreoni|first=James|date=1990|title=Impure Altruism and Donations to Public Goods: A Theory of Warm-Glow Giving|url=http://www.jstor.org/stable/2234133|journal=The Economic Journal|volume=100|issue=401|pages=464–477|doi=10.2307/2234133}}</ref> Warm glow is at least tangentially related to the topic of [[free will]], as people should only reap the psychological reward of helping if they freely choose to do so.<ref name=":14" />
== Background in economics ==
=== Departure from Classical theory ===
The normative theory of [[Ricardian equivalence]] suggests that private spending should be unresponsive to [[fiscal policy]] because forward-looking individuals smooth their consumption,<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/1048898019|title=Macroeconomics|last=R.,|first=Krugman, Paul|others=Wells, Robin, 1959-|isbn=9781319098759|edition=Fifth edition|location=New York, NY|oclc=1048898019}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|url=http://worldcat.org/oclc/1027353872|title=Reflections on Ricardian Equivalence|last=J.|first=Barro, Robert|date=1996|publisher=National Bureau of Economic Research|oclc=1027353872}}</ref> consistent with Modigliani's [[life-cycle hypothesis]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=MODIGLIANI|first=FRANCO|date=1966|title=THE LIFE CYCLE HYPOTHESIS OF SAVING, THE DEMAND FOR WEALTH AND THE SUPPLY OF CAPITAL|url=http://www.jstor.org/stable/40969831|journal=Social Research|volume=33|issue=2|pages=160–217}}</ref> Applied to the provision of charities or [[Public good|public goods]], Ricardian equivalence and the classical assumption of pure altruism together support the neutrality hypothesis,<ref name=":14" /> implying perfect substitutability between private and public contributions. The neutrality hypothesis assumes rational economic agents are indifferent to whether a cause is funded by the private or public sector; only the level of funding is relevant.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bergstrom|first=Theodore|last2=Blume|first2=Lawrence|last3=Varian|first3=Hal|date=1986|title=On the private provision of public goods|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/0047-2727(86)90024-1|journal=Journal of Public Economics|volume=29|issue=1|pages=25–49|doi=10.1016/0047-2727(86)90024-1|issn=0047-2727|via=}}</ref> A consequence of neutrality under perfect altruism is that government grants should completely crowd-out private donations. That is, a dollar given by the government takes the place of a dollar that would have been given by a private citizen.<ref name=":26">{{Cite journal|last=Yildirim|first=Huseyin|date=2014|title=Andreoni–McGuire algorithm and the limits of warm-glow giving|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jpubeco.2013.09.005|journal=Journal of Public Economics|volume=114|pages=101–107|doi=10.1016/j.jpubeco.2013.09.005|issn=0047-2727|via=}}</ref> To illustrate, economic agents operating under the neutrality hypothesis would give to a cause until complete provision, beyond which they would contribute nothing<ref name=":2" />. This is consistent with Andreoni's conceptualization of "pure altruism"; however it is inconsistent with impure altruism or pure egoism.<ref name=":26" /> Thus, warm glow and the failure to act as purely altruistic present fundamental challenges to the neutrality hypothesis and Ricardian equivalence.<ref name=":14" /><ref name=":242">{{Cite journal|last=Menges|first=Roland|last2=Schroeder|first2=Carsten|last3=Traub|first3=Stefan|date=2005|title=Altruism, Warm Glow and the Willingness-to-Donate for Green Electricity: An Artefactual Field Experiment|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s10640-005-3365-y|journal=Environmental & Resource Economics|volume=31|issue=4|pages=431–458|doi=10.1007/s10640-005-3365-y|issn=0924-6460|via=}}</ref> In economics, violations to the neutrality hypothesis pose serious concerns for macroeconomic policies involving taxation and redistribution; and microeconomic theories for [[Collective action problem|collective action]]<nowiki/>and [[Public good|public good provision]].<ref name=":22" /> Several of Andreoni's contemporaries simultaneously provided evidence against neutrality-driven crowding-out effects, including Kingma (1989)<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kingma|first=Bruce|date=1989|title=An Accurate Measurement of the Crowd-out Effect, Income Effect, and Price Effect for Charitable Contributions|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1086/261649|journal=Journal of Political Economy|volume=97|issue=5|pages=1197–1207|doi=10.1086/261649|issn=0022-3808|via=}}</ref> and Khanna et al. (1995)<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Khanna|first=Jyoti|last2=Posnett|first2=John|last3=Sandler|first3=Todd|date=1995|title=Charity donations in the UK: New evidence based on panel data|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/0047-2727(94)01421-j|journal=Journal of Public Economics|volume=56|issue=2|pages=257–272|doi=10.1016/0047-2727(94)01421-j|issn=0047-2727|via=}}</ref>. Taken together, these findings offered a strong rebuke of the assumption that public grants crowd-out private donations to public goods.<ref name=":242" /> === Original model === Andreoni's economic model of impure altruism considers a simplistic world with only two goods: a [[private good]] and a [[public good]]. A given individual, endowed with wealth <math>(w_{i}),</math>faces the [[budget constraint]]: <math>w_{i} = x_{i} + g_{i}, </math>where <math>x_{i} </math>represents consumption of a private good, and <math>g_{i}</math>represents the contribution to the public good. To the extent that <math>g_i </math>positively contributes to [[utility]], it may be interpreted as the degree of warm glow.<ref name=":22" />It follows that the total provision of the public good, G, is simply: <math>\sum_{i}^{n} (g_{i}),</math>and the total contributions to the public good from all other individuals is denoted as: <math>G_{-i} = \sum_{i \ne j}^n(g_{j}).</math>Thus, the public good is the sum of the <math>i^{th} </math>person's contribution <math>(g_{i}),</math>along with the total contributions of all other individuals <math>G_{-i}. </math>
'''(1) <math>G = g_{i} + G_{-i},</math>'''where <math>g_i \ge 0.</math>
All individuals in this naïve economy face the same [[utility function]]<nowiki/>s, given by:
'''(2)'''<math>U_{i} = U_{i}(x_{i},G,g_{i}),</math>
where the utility functions represent the utility for private, egoistic consumption <math>U_{i}(x_{i});</math>the utility derived from the public good <math>U_{i}(G);</math>and the warm-glow utility of the contribution towards the public good <math>U_{i}(g_{i}).</math>An altruist should derive no additional utility from the act of giving: <math>U_{altruist} = f(x_i, G),</math>whereas a pure egoist derives pleasure only from the warm glow of giving, without care for the public good itself, hence <math>U_{egoist} = f(x_i,g_i).</math>
From the budget constraint and utility function, one can derive the utility maximization function, <math>max U_{i}(w_{i}+G_{-i}-G, G, G - G_{-i}),</math>which is the original utility function '''(2)''' transformed using the definition of the public good '''(1)'''.<ref name=":22" />
=== Implications === Assuming a strategy of utility maximization, the model of warm glow offers many important economic predictions. Specifically, it presents three contrarian insights to those of classical economics under Ricardian equivalence.<ref name=":22" />
First, warm-glow theory predicts that income transfers will increase net giving only when income is transferred to more altruistic individuals. Second, it suggests that the provision of a public good is dependent upon the distribution of income within a population. Third, it suggests that public fund of public goods through lump-sum taxes will be more effective than relying upon altruism in the private sector.<ref name=":22" /> Individually and collectively, these propositions are in stark contrast to the [[laissez-faire]] doctrine of Ricardian economics.<ref name=":14" /> Following this original model, warm glow has conceptually evolved with new applications across disciplines to explain and encourage [[prosocial behavior]].<ref name=":10">{{Cite journal|last=Andreoni|first=James|last2=Rao|first2=Justin|last3=Trachtman|first3=Hannah|date=2017|title=Avoiding the Ask: A Field Experiment on Altruism, Empathy, and Charitable Giving|url=|journal=Journal of Political Economy|volume=125|pages=|via=}}</ref> == Background in psychology == Many of the advances in warm glow research stem not from economics, but from psychology. In particular, research on motivations and affect have played a key role in defining and operationalizing warm glow for broad application.<ref name=":103">{{Cite journal|last=Andreoni|first=James|last2=Rao|first2=Justin|last3=Trachtman|first3=Hannah|date=2017|title=Avoiding the Ask: A Field Experiment on Altruism, Empathy, and Charitable Giving|url=|journal=Journal of Political Economy|volume=125|pages=|via=}}</ref>
=== A motivational perspective === ''"...a millionaire does not really care whether his money does good or not, provided he finds his conscience eased and his social status improved by giving it away..." -George Bernard Shaw.''<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Shaw|first=George Bernard|date=1896|title=Shaw On Socialism (1896)|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.14452/mr-002-08-1950-12_5|journal=Monthly Review|volume=2|issue=8|pages=387|doi=10.14452/mr-002-08-1950-12_5|issn=0027-0520|via=}}</ref>
As illustrated in Shaw's quote, both intrinsic desires of conscience and extrinsic desires of social status may motivate giving. Warm glow has traditionally been restricted to intrinsic motivation,<ref name=":162">{{Cite journal|last=Tonin|first=Mirco|last2=Vlassopoulos|first2=Michael|date=2013-03-27|title=An experimental investigation of intrinsic motivations for giving|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s11238-013-9360-9|journal=Theory and Decision|volume=76|issue=1|pages=47–67|doi=10.1007/s11238-013-9360-9|issn=0040-5833}}</ref> however this distinction is often murky.<ref name=":302">{{Cite journal|last=Scharf|first=Kimberley|last2=Smith|first2=Sarah|date=2016|title=Relational altruism and giving in social groups|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jpubeco.2016.06.001|journal=Journal of Public Economics|volume=141|pages=1–10|doi=10.1016/j.jpubeco.2016.06.001|issn=0047-2727|via=}}</ref>

==== Extrinsic warm glow ==== Much of the ambiguity surrounding the motivational processes of warm glow has arisen from the misclassification of extrinsic rewards to intrinsic processes.<ref name=":72">{{Cite book|title=The Valmont Effect: The Warm-Glow Theory of Philanthropy|last=Elster|first=Jon|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2011|isbn=978-0-19-973907-3|location=|pages=67-83}}</ref><ref name=":27">{{Cite journal|last=Tonin|first=Mirco|last2=Vlassopoulos|first2=Michael|date=2010|title=Disentangling the sources of pro-socially motivated effort: A field experiment|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jpubeco.2010.08.011|journal=Journal of Public Economics|volume=94|issue=11-12|pages=1086–1092|doi=10.1016/j.jpubeco.2010.08.011|issn=0047-2727|via=}}</ref> While intrinsic desires center upon emotional gains, extrinsic rewards may include recognition, identity signaling, and prestige. Extrinsic motivation may also take the form of punishment (negative warm glow), in the form of censure or blame<ref name=":11">{{Cite journal|last=Ryan|first=Richard M.|last2=Deci|first2=Edward L.|date=2000|title=Self-determination theory and the facilitation of intrinsic motivation, social development, and well-being.|url=http://doi.apa.org/getdoi.cfm?doi=10.1037/0003-066X.55.1.68|journal=American Psychologist|language=en|volume=55|issue=1|pages=68–78|doi=10.1037/0003-066x.55.1.68|issn=1935-990X}}</ref>. Some research has explicitly focused on extrinsic warm glow, such as "relational warm glow".<ref name=":30">{{Cite journal|last=Scharf|first=Kimberley|last2=Smith|first2=Sarah|date=2016|title=Relational altruism and giving in social groups|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jpubeco.2016.06.001|journal=Journal of Public Economics|volume=141|pages=1–10|doi=10.1016/j.jpubeco.2016.06.001|issn=0047-2727|via=}}</ref>
One area that has been frequently confused in the literature involves the classification of guilt, which is an introjected form of extrinsic motivation.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Gagné|first=Marylène|last2=Deci|first2=Edward L.|date=2005-04-14|title=Self-determination theory and work motivation|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1002/job.322|journal=Journal of Organizational Behavior|volume=26|issue=4|pages=331–362|doi=10.1002/job.322|issn=0894-3796}}</ref>
==== Importance of motivational classification ==== The classification of warm glow as either intrinsic or extrinsic has important ramifications for policy makers.<ref name=":122">{{Cite journal|last=D'Amato|first=Alessio|last2=Mancinelli|first2=Susanna|last3=Zoli|first3=Mariangela|date=2014|title=Two Shades of (Warm) Glow: multidimensional intrinsic motivation, waste reduction and recycling|url=http://www.sustainability-seeds.org/papers/RePec/srt/wpaper/2114.pdf|journal=Working Paper|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> The extensive body of literature on [[Motivation crowding theory|motivational crowding out]] suggests the efficacy of policies promoting altruistic behavior may be a function of whether pre-existing behavior is intrinsically or extrinsically motivated.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Frey|first=Bruno S.|last2=Jegen|first2=Reto|date=2001|title=Motivation Crowding Theory|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1111/1467-6419.00150|journal=Journal of Economic Surveys|volume=15|issue=5|pages=589–611|doi=10.1111/1467-6419.00150|issn=0950-0804|via=}}</ref><ref name=":6">{{Citation|last=Deci|first=Edward L.|title=Conceptualizations of Intrinsic Motivation and Self-Determination|date=1985|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/978-1-4899-2271-7_2|work=Intrinsic Motivation and Self-Determination in Human Behavior|pages=11–40|publisher=Springer US|isbn=9781489922731|access-date=2018-11-09|last2=Ryan|first2=Richard M.}}</ref> The extent to which extrinsic incentives may be substitutes for intrinsic motivations depends upon the motivational classification of the warm glow model. Furthermore, intrinsic warm glow may be more resilient to satiation effects than extrinsic warm glow.<ref name=":16">{{Cite journal|last=Tonin|first=Mirco|last2=Vlassopoulos|first2=Michael|date=2013-03-27|title=An experimental investigation of intrinsic motivations for giving|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s11238-013-9360-9|journal=Theory and Decision|volume=76|issue=1|pages=47–67|doi=10.1007/s11238-013-9360-9|issn=0040-5833}}</ref> Finally, the expected magnitude of a warm glow will be a function of how it is characterized. Models assuming a purely intrinsic warm glow should report lesser warm glows than models also including extrinsic components.<ref name=":15" />
=== Empathy and the psychological determinants of warm glow === [[File:Empathy_-_Design_Thinking.png|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Empathy_-_Design_Thinking.png|thumb|Empathy - Design
