Taken together, these observations suggest the warm glow may be best described as the visceral manifestation of [[empathy]].<ref name=":102" /><ref name=":5" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Andreychik|first=Michael R.|last2=Migliaccio|first2=Nicole|date=2015-08-18|title=Empathizing With Others’ Pain Versus Empathizing With Others’ Joy: Examining the Separability of Positive and Negative Empathy and Their Relation to Different Types of Social Behaviors and Social Emotions|url=https://www.tandfonline.com/action/captchaChallenge?redirectUri=%2Fdoi%2Ffull%2F10.1080%2F01973533.2015.1071256|journal=Basic and Applied Social Psychology|language=en|volume=37|issue=5|pages=274–291|doi=10.1080/01973533.2015.1071256|issn=0197-3533}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Erlandsson|first=Arvid|last2=Jungstrand|first2=Amanda Å.|last3=Västfjäll|first3=Daniel|date=2016-09-28|title=Anticipated Guilt for Not Helping and Anticipated Warm Glow for Helping Are Differently Impacted by Personal Responsibility to Help|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.3389/fpsyg.2016.01475|journal=Frontiers in Psychology|volume=7|doi=10.3389/fpsyg.2016.01475|issn=1664-1078}}</ref> This is consistent with the moral psychological literature of empathy, most notably as advanced by [[Daniel Batson|Batson]].<ref name=":192">{{Citation|last=Doris|first=John|title=Moral Psychology: Empirical Approaches|date=2017|url=https://plato.stanford.edu/archives/win2017/entries/moral-psych-emp/|work=The Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy|editor-last=Zalta|editor-first=Edward N.|edition=Winter 2017|publisher=Metaphysics Research Lab, Stanford University|access-date=2018-11-16|last2=Stich|first2=Stephen|last3=Phillips|first3=Jonathan|last4=Walmsley|first4=Lachlan}}</ref> In his "empathy-altruism hypothesis", Batson claims that empathy ("feeling sympathetic, compassionate, warm, softhearted, tender") evokes a desire for other-regarding behavior.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Batson|first=C. Daniel|date=2014-01-02|title=The Altruism Question|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.4324/9781315808048|doi=10.4324/9781315808048}}</ref>
==== Social distance ==== [[Social distance]] is an important determinant of warm glow, particularly in the framework of empathy.<ref name=":192" /> Prior research has examined the link between emotional arousal and social distance, finding that mutual suffering and shared joy both increase as a function of social similarity.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Krebs|first=Dennis|date=1975|title=Empathy and altruism.|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1037//0022-3514.32.6.1134|journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology|volume=32|issue=6|pages=1134–1146|doi=10.1037//0022-3514.32.6.1134|issn=0022-3514}}</ref> Consistent with the "[[identifiable victim effect]]",<ref>{{Cite journal|last=JENNI|first=KAREN|last2=LOEWENSTEIN|first2=GEORGE|date=1997|title=Explaining the identifiable victim effect|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1023/a:1007740225484|journal=Journal of Risk and Uncertainty|volume=14|issue=3|pages=235–257|doi=10.1023/a:1007740225484|issn=0895-5646|via=}}</ref> research has shown that people express a greater willingness to help when others are known, as opposed to statistical.<ref name=":23" /> ==== Vividness to beneficiary ==== While the vividness of the beneficiary is captured in social distance,<ref name=":222" /> the vividness to the beneficiary refers to a beneficiary's ability to perceive that kindness has been done upon them. As a determinant of warm glow, vividness to the beneficiary operates on two levels. The primary level concerns whether a beneficiary is aware that kindness has been given to them, absent any attribution of the source. The secondary level involves the identifiability of the benefactor. Warm glow should be positively impacted by both levels for vividness.<ref name=":102" />
==== Guilt ==== Recent work has identified guilt avoidance as an important component of warm glow.<ref name=":102" /> Some have even compared guilt as the "flip side" of warm glow.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Giebelhausen|first=Michael|last2=Chun|first2=HaeEun Helen|last3=Cronin|first3=J. Joseph|last4=Hult|first4=G. Tomas M.|date=2016|title=Adjusting the Warm-Glow Thermostat: How Incentivizing Participation in Voluntary Green Programs Moderates Their Impact on Service Satisfaction|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1509/jm.14.0497|journal=Journal of Marketing|volume=80|issue=4|pages=56–71|doi=10.1509/jm.14.0497|issn=0022-2429|via=}}</ref> Parameterizing guilt as a component of warm glow allows for deficit values of warm glow, which was originally constrained to strictly positive values in Andreoni (1989, 1990).<ref name=":5" /> In a recent publication, Andreoni and colleagues explain this by writing: ''"Psychologists posit that giving is initiated by a stimulus that elevates sympathy or empathy in the mind of the potential giver, much as the smell of freshly baked bread can pique appetite. Resolving this feeling comes either by giving and feeling good or by not giving and feeling guilt."''<ref name=":102" /> In other notable overviews of warm glow, this phenomenon has been characterized as "personal distress"<ref name=":172">{{Citation|last=Singer|first=Peter|title=What Should a Billionaire Give—and What Should You?|date=2011-01-13|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1093/acprof:oso/9780199739073.003.0002|work=Giving Well|pages=13–24|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780199739073|access-date=2018-11-08}}</ref>. In surveys of self-reported guilt, people experience roughly as much interpersonal and societal guilt as they do personal guilt. Furthermore, half of the survey respondents prefer to directly address and resolve their feelings of guilt. Taken together, these findings suggest a substantial component of guilt aversion.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Dahl|first=Darren W.|last2=Honea|first2=Heather|last3=Manchanda|first3=Rajesh V.|date=2003|title=The Nature of Self-Reported Guilt in Consumption Contexts|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1023/a:1027492516677|journal=Marketing Letters|volume=14|issue=3|pages=159–171|doi=10.1023/a:1027492516677|issn=0923-0645|via=}}</ref>
== Neurological evidence == [[File:FMRI-scan_sectie_85.JPG|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:FMRI-scan_sectie_85.JPG|alt=|left|thumb|fMRI studies reveal the warm glow of donating in the subgeneal area and ventral striatum<ref name=":20">{{Cite journal|last=Moll|first=J.|last2=Krueger|first2=F.|last3=Zahn|first3=R.|last4=Pardini|first4=M.|last5=de Oliveira-Souza|first5=R.|last6=Grafman|first6=J.|date=2006-10-09|title=Human fronto-mesolimbic networks guide decisions about charitable donation|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1073/pnas.0604475103|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|volume=103|issue=42|pages=15623–15628|doi=10.1073/pnas.0604475103|issn=0027-8424}}</ref>]] Evidence from neural imaging supports the warm-glow effect. Recent research using [[functional magnetic resonance imaging]] of subjects making donation decisions identifies the [[Brodmann area 25|subgeneal area]] and the [[ventral striatum]] as regions associated with social giving.<ref name=":20" /> The mesolimbic rewards of giving are neurologically similar to receiving material rewards.<ref name=":74">{{Cite book|title=The Valmont Effect: The Warm-Glow Theory of Philanthropy|last=Elster|first=Jon|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=2011|isbn=978-0-19-973907-3|location=|pages=67-83}}</ref><ref name=":20" /> While there is some evidence for a "literal warm glow" - in which an individual's perceived thermal state is elevated by the act of giving due to activation in the insula<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Taufik|first=Danny|last2=Bolderdijk|first2=Jan Willem|last3=Steg|first3=Linda|date=2014-11-24|title=Acting green elicits a literal warm glow|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/nclimate2449|journal=Nature Climate Change|volume=5|issue=1|pages=37–40|doi=10.1038/nclimate2449|issn=1758-678X}}</ref> - the more general consensus across the psychological and neurobiological fields is that helping others makes people happy through the release of the oxytocin<ref name=":20" /> and endorphins.<ref name=":182">{{Cite journal|last=Baraz|first=James|last2=Alexander|first2=Shoshana|date=2010|title=The Helper's High|url=https://greatergood.berkeley.edu/article/item/the_helpers_high|journal=Greater Good Magazine|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref>
== Other applications == === Voting === [[File:I_voted_15016301.png|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:I_voted_15016301.png|thumb|Early iterations of warm glow examined the decision to vote<ref name=":212">{{Cite journal|last=Riker|first=William H.|last2=Ordeshook|first2=Peter C.|date=1968|title=A Theory of the Calculus of Voting|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1017/s000305540011562x|journal=American Political Science Review|volume=62|issue=01|pages=25–42|doi=10.1017/s000305540011562x|issn=0003-0554|via=}}</ref>]] One of the earliest attempts to formally model the warm glow phenomenon can be found in "A Theory of the Calculus of Voting" by Riker and Ordeshook (1968).<ref name=":212" /> Resolving the paradox by which rational individuals would never expend the effort to vote due to the statistical near-improbability of "having their vote count" (casting the decisive vote), Riker and Ordeshook highlighted the psychological utility of voting for one's preferred candidate. Just as an economic warm glow motivates people to willingly forego their scarce resources, the psychological utility described in early voting models serves to explain otherwise irrational behavior.<ref name=":212" /> The warm glow of voting continues to be an important consideration in ethical voter models.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Feddersen|first=Timothy J|date=2004|title=Rational Choice Theory and the Paradox of Not Voting|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1257/089533004773563458|journal=Journal of Economic Perspectives|volume=18|issue=1|pages=99–112|doi=10.1257/089533004773563458|issn=0895-3309|via=}}</ref>
=== Environmental policy === In efforts to design effective, enduring, and efficient environmental interventions, many scholars and policy makers have focused on warm-glow effects.<ref name=":124">{{Cite journal|last=D'Amato|first=Alessio|last2=Mancinelli|first2=Susanna|last3=Zoli|first3=Mariangela|date=2014|title=Two Shades of (Warm) Glow: multidimensional intrinsic motivation, waste reduction and recycling|url=http://www.sustainability-seeds.org/papers/RePec/srt/wpaper/2114.pdf|journal=Working Paper|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref> Because many forms of extrinsic rewards and punishments have failed to promote long-term improvements in environmentally conscious behavior,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Viscusi|first=W. Kip|last2=Huber|first2=Joel|last3=Bell|first3=Jason|date=2011|title=Promoting Recycling: Private Values, Social Norms, and Economic Incentives|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1257/aer.101.3.65|journal=American Economic Review|volume=101|issue=3|pages=65–70|doi=10.1257/aer.101.3.65|issn=0002-8282|via=}}</ref> there is a growing emphasis on intrinsic warm glow.<ref name=":124" /> Intervention experiments offer promising results in areas such as supporting green energy,<ref name=":243">{{Cite journal|last=Menges|first=Roland|last2=Schroeder|first2=Carsten|last3=Traub|first3=Stefan|date=2005|title=Altruism, Warm Glow and the Willingness-to-Donate for Green Electricity: An Artefactual Field Experiment|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s10640-005-3365-y|journal=Environmental & Resource Economics|volume=31|issue=4|pages=431–458|doi=10.1007/s10640-005-3365-y|issn=0924-6460|via=}}</ref> recycling and waste reduction,<ref name=":124" /> energy consumption,<ref name=":133">{{Cite journal|last=van der Linden|first=Sander|date=2015|title=Intrinsic motivation and pro-environmental behaviour|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1038/nclimate2669|journal=Nature Climate Change|volume=5|issue=7|pages=612–613|doi=10.1038/nclimate2669|issn=1758-678X|via=}}</ref> carpooling initiatives.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sexton|first=Steven E.|date=2012-08-14|title=Paying for Pollution? How General Equilibrium Effects Undermine the “Spare the Air” Program|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1007/s10640-012-9577-z|journal=Environmental and Resource Economics|volume=53|issue=4|pages=553–575|doi=10.1007/s10640-012-9577-z|issn=0924-6460}}</ref>
=== Business ===
==== Corporate social responsibility ==== Supporting businesses engaged in [[corporate social responsibility]] (CSR) initiatives may give consumers a vicarious warm glow. However, recent research suggests that consumers may expect to overpay when companies engage in CSR due to perceptions of price fairness. The implication that "doing good" carries a financial burden for businesses leads consumers to infer general price markups. This body of research cautions that corporate warm glows may be coupled with "cold prickles" of extra costs.<ref name=":292">{{Cite journal|last=Habel|first=Johannes|last2=Schons|first2=Laura Marie|last3=Alavi|first3=Sascha|last4=Wieseke|first4=Jan|date=2016|title=Warm Glow or Extra Charge? The Ambivalent Effect of Corporate Social Responsibility Activities on Customers’ Perceived Price Fairness|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1509/jm.14.0389|journal=Journal of Marketing|volume=80|issue=1|pages=84–105|doi=10.1509/jm.14.0389|issn=0022-2429|via=}}</ref> ==== Product advertising ==== Warm glow can be a central element of [[cause marketing]], in which products are paired with donations. When consumers are exposed to products with a direct cause marketing association, their appraisal of both the product and the company may improve due to warm glow.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Andrews|first=Michelle|last2=Luo|first2=Xueming|last3=Fang|first3=Zheng|last4=Aspara|first4=Jaakko|date=2014|title=Cause Marketing Effectiveness and the Moderating Role of Price Discounts|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1509/jm.14.0003|journal=Journal of Marketing|volume=78|issue=6|pages=120–142|doi=10.1509/jm.14.0003|issn=0022-2429|via=}}</ref> There is also evidence that product warm glows may play a role in a process called "hedonic licensing", in which consumers who perceive a moral surplus subsequently allow themselves more leeway to make selfish purchases.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Khan|first=Uzma|last2=Dhar|first2=Ravi|date=2006|title=Licensing Effect in Consumer Choice|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1509/jmkr.43.2.259|journal=Journal of Marketing Research|volume=43|issue=2|pages=259–266|doi=10.1509/jmkr.43.2.259|issn=0022-2437|via=}}</ref>
=== Philanthropy ===
==== Avoidance behaviors ==== [[File:IYC_Women_Bell_Ringers_2016_(31029903216).jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:IYC_Women_Bell_Ringers_2016_(31029903216).jpg|alt=|left|thumb|"Negative" warm glow may explain why empathetic individuals actively avoid charitable opportunities]] Common phenomena such as avoiding eye contact with beggars or adjusting one's route to avoid a solicitor may be explained using the warm glow model.
One behavioral consequence of warm glow is strategic avoidance of giving opportunities. According to this hypothesis, individuals anticipate their warm glow upon identifying a future giving opportunity. Assuming a functional form that allows warm glow to be negative (driven by a ''guilt'' of not giving), people may strategically and effortfully avoid giving situations. The strategic incentive is easily understood through the utility function <math>U_i = U_{i}(x_{i},G,g_{i}), </math>where the warm glow <math>(g_i),</math>is positive for a donation (joy of giving) and negative for not giving (guilt). For an agent who would suffer a disutility of giving at their desired level <math>(g_i^*)</math>because the marginal utility of private expenditure <math>(x_i)</math>exceeds the marginal utility of warm-glow giving, they should prefer to give nothing <math>(g_i^0).</math>Because giving nothing may be associated with guilt, the utility of <math>(g_i^0)</math>will be negative. Therefore, for a rational agent who cannot justify giving, <math>U_i(x_i,G,g_i^*) < U_i(x_i,G,g_i^0) </math>, can maximize their utility through avoiding a giving situation, effectively dropping the warm glow argument from their utility functions.<ref name=":10" /> Thus, <math>U_i(x_i,G,g_i^*) < U_i(x_i,G,g_i^0) < U_i(x_i, G, 0)</math>suggests avoidance of giving opportunities is a preferred strategy for individuals who experience guilt as a negative warm glow. Economic models assign a cost of effort to avoidance, and predict that people will incur such effort whenever <math>U_{i0} - c_i > U_{is},</math>where <math>U_{i0}</math>is the utility of not giving, <math>c_i</math>is the cost of avoidance, and <math>U_{is}</math>is the utility of giving to a solicitor, conditional upon not avoiding.<ref name=":10" />
Through this lens, avoidance can be viewed as an economic [[commitment device]], where a person commits to avoiding a situation (being asked to give) in which they are likely to surrender to temptation (giving). Central to this avoidance hypothesis is that individuals can anticipate their behavior in high-empathy "hot states", while in low-empathy "cold states". While this model assumes a high degree of sophistication on the part of the individual, research by Andreoni, Rao, and Trachtman explores this very phenomenon by observing avoidance and donation behavior of customers entering a supermarket during the holidays. Customers often walked to a further entrance to avoid solicitors for the Salvation Army. According to their model, "empathetically vulnerable" individuals who are not be able to give (for budgetary reasons), faced the greatest incentive to avoid collectors because of the guilt they would experience upon saying "no".<ref name=":52">{{Cite book|url=http://worldcat.org/oclc/934199169|title=The economics of philanthropy and fundraising|last=editor.|first=Andreoni, James,|isbn=9781784713232|oclc=934199169}}</ref>
==== Grouping behaviors ==== Charities may strategically employ categorical [[Donor recognition wall|donor recognition]]. For example, a charitable organization may distinguish any gift between $500-$999.99 by a title distinct from that awarded for gifts above $1,000. As a consequence, the social signaling component of the warm-glow effect (in extrinsic operationalizations of warm glow) suggests individuals should be motivated to make the minimum donation to acquire their desired categorical status. Consistent with this hypothesis, research has indicated significant grouping behavior of donors around category minimums.<ref name=":25">{{Cite journal|last=Harbaugh|first=William T|date=1998|title=What do donations buy?|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/s0047-2727(97)00062-5|journal=Journal of Public Economics|volume=67|issue=2|pages=269–284|doi=10.1016/s0047-2727(97)00062-5|issn=0047-2727|via=}}</ref>
==== Inefficiency in charitable allocation ====
A majority of those who choose to give some portion of their wealth to charity support multiple different causes. Rather than giving 100% of their cumulative donations to the same source, there exists a widespread preference to distribute funds across charities.<ref name=":173">{{Citation|last=Singer|first=Peter|title=What Should a Billionaire Give—and What Should You?|date=2011-01-13|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1093/acprof:oso/9780199739073.003.0002|work=Giving Well|pages=13–24|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=9780199739073|access-date=2018-11-08}}</ref> The warm glow model explains this be recognizing that givers receive multiple warm glows by giving to multiple causes, thus supporting the preference to make many smaller contributions. As a consequence, some scholars suggest an efficiency loss due to high volumes of small donations - which are less efficient to process - rather than fewer large donations.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Null|first=C.|date=2011|title=Warm glow, information, and inefficient charitable giving|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jpubeco.2010.06.018|journal=Journal of Public Economics|volume=95|issue=5-6|pages=455–465|doi=10.1016/j.jpubeco.2010.06.018|issn=0047-2727|via=}}</ref> Moral philosopher [[Peter Singer]]<nowiki/>mentions warm-glow givers in his 2015 book, ''[[The Most Good You Can Do]]''. Singer states that these types of donors "give small amounts to many charities [and] are not so interested in whether what they are doing helps others." He references "empathetic concern" and "personal distress" as two distinct components of warm-glow givers.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Most Good You Can Do: How Effective Altruism Is Changing Ideas About Living Ethically.|last=Singer|first=Peter|publisher=New Haven: Yale University Press|year=2015|isbn=|location=|pages=pp. 5, 6, 77–80, 90.}}</ref>
==== Inefficiency in charitable selection ====
Warm glow may offer an explanation for some of the observed inefficiencies in charitable giving. For example, United States citizens directed more than 60% of their total charitable contributions to religious groups, education institutions, art organizations, and foundations in 2017; compared to under 7% in foreign aid.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://givingusa.org|title=Giving USA {{!}} A public service initiative of the Giving Institute|website=givingusa.org|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-08}}</ref> According to models of social justice<ref name=":173" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.globalpolicyjournal.com/blog/24/02/2014/donors%E2%80%99-dilemma-charity-social-justice|title='The Donors’ Dilemma' - From Charity to Social Justice {{!}} Global Policy Journal|website=www.globalpolicyjournal.com|language=en|access-date=2018-11-08}}</ref> and economic [[Quality-adjusted life year|QALY]]<nowiki/>s,<ref name=":9" /> in which human lives are treated with equal dignity and equal respect - regardless of race, gender, or place of origin - the goal of charity should be to fight global poverty. Similarly, economic models, which attempt to place a monetary value on the human life<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theglobalist.com/the-cost-of-a-human-life-statistically-speaking/|title=The Cost of a Human Life, Statistically Speaking - The Globalist|date=2012-07-21|work=The Globalist|access-date=2018-11-08|language=en-US}}</ref>, highlight the inefficiency of all philanthropy not used to combat global poverty, which offers the highest marginal return.<ref name=":02">{{Cite book|url=http://worldcat.org/oclc/987462476|title=Doing good better effective altruism and a radical new way to make a difference|last=VerfasserIn.|first=MacAskill, William,|isbn=9781783350513|oclc=987462476}}</ref> The warm-glow model accounts for such inefficiency because impure altruists may be insensitive to the actual cause, and more sensitive to the act of giving or size of the gift. Thus, warm-glow may generate philanthropic inefficiencies to the extent that it desensitizes potential donors to the marginal impact of a given charity. In response to this concern, [[William MacAskill|Willian MacAskill]] and colleagues have advanced a process of philanthropic allocation called "[[effective altruism]]".<ref name=":02" /> This methodology seeks to leverage logic and responsibility to identify effective charitable opportunities, thus minimizing the effect of warm-glow in the decision-making process.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.psychologicalscience.org/publications/observer/obsonline/the-warm-glow-of-giving-may-overshadow-doing-the-greatest-good.html|title=The “Warm Glow” of Giving May Overshadow Doing the Greatest Good|work=Association for Psychological Science|access-date=2018-11-08|language=en-US}}</ref><ref name=":9">{{Cite book|url=|title=Doing good better : how effective altruism can help you help others, do work that matters, and make smarter choices about giving back|last=2016|first=MacAskill, William,|publisher=|year=|isbn=1592409660|location=New York, N.Y.|pages=|oclc=932001639}}</ref>
== Criticisms == === Ad-hoc === A common criticism of the warm-glow paradigm is that it seems ad-hoc. Indeed, Andreoni, the father of the original model, stated that "putting warm-glow into the model is, while intuitively appealing, an admittedly ''ad hoc'' fix".<ref name=":28">{{Citation|last=Andreoni|first=James|title=Chapter 18 Philanthropy|date=2006|url=https://doi.org/10.1016/S1574-0714(06)02018-5|work=Handbook of the Economics of Giving, Altruism and Reciprocity|pages=1201–1269|publisher=Elsevier|doi=10.1016/s1574-0714(06)02018-5|isbn=9780444521453|access-date=2018-11-16}}</ref> As the body of research has evolved over nearly 30 years - incorporating philosophical,<ref name=":173" /> psychological,<ref name=":232">{{Cite journal|last=Small|first=Deborah A.|last2=Loewenstein|first2=George|date=2003|title=Help a Victim or Helping the Victim: Altruism and Identifiability|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1023/a:1022299422219|journal=Journal of Risk and Uncertainty|volume=26|issue=1|pages=5–16|doi=10.1023/a:1022299422219|issn=0895-5646|via=}}</ref> and physiological insights<ref name=":20" /> - it has become a better descriptive model of behavior.<ref name=":104">{{Cite journal|last=Andreoni|first=James|last2=Rao|first2=Justin|last3=Trachtman|first3=Hannah|date=2017|title=Avoiding the Ask: A Field Experiment on Altruism, Empathy, and Charitable Giving|url=|journal=Journal of Political Economy|volume=125|pages=|via=}}</ref>
=== Self-delusion === An obscure criticism of the warm-glow paradigm is that it necessitates self-deception.<ref name=":74" /> This argument states that in order to reap the emotional reward of helping others, one must believe his actions to be motivated altruistically. Yet, the mere existence of a warm glow should then contradict the belief of pure altruism. A question arises as to whether prolonged self-delusion is sustainable and impervious to learning through [[Self-perception theory|self-perception]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bem|first=Daryl J.|date=1967|title=Self-perception: An alternative interpretation of cognitive dissonance phenomena.|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1037/h0024835|journal=Psychological Review|volume=74|issue=3|pages=183–200|doi=10.1037/h0024835|issn=1939-1471}}</ref>
== Extensions == Some research has investigated the link between warm glow and the phenomenon of [[Mere-exposure effect|mere exposure]], leading researchers to consider warm glow as a [[heuristic]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Monin|first=Benoît|date=2003|title=The Warm Glow Heuristic: When Liking Leads to Familiarity.|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1037/0022-3514.85.6.1035|journal=Journal of Personality and Social Psychology|volume=85|issue=6|pages=1035–1048|doi=10.1037/0022-3514.85.6.1035|issn=1939-1315}}</ref>
